Posts.EditableText:
I got one... (kinda), still working on it, but it is too liner for me...
But here was the notes for the first version if anyone wants to know...
---------------------------------------
knock, knock...
you get up
there is a small pink bunny at the door, holding a small grass weaved basket with several colorful eggs
lieing in a bed of green grass.
"I need your help to hide my eggs for tomorrow and I'm running out of time, please help..."
So, you're the Easter Bunny???
Um, yea, sure... but I really need your help
Help? yes or no...
No... sorry, but I gota get up early to get to work...
Yes... Sure, you help the bunny...
several rooms, 'hide' eggs everywhere...
when done, you go back to bed...
You are awaken by shouting and explosions...
Outside it is a war zone...
Little pink bunnies with big guns are shooting eggs at houses where they explode and burn the houses.
Police and others with guns are shooting at the bunnies...
There are people and bunnies lieing everywhere.
You hear someone calling out orders on the left and see a big pink bunny that looks
alot like the one from last night.
He hops over to your window and leans on the sill,
"Thanks for the help last night, with out you, I could not have gotten all the portal eggs in place in time...
That's why we are sparing your house." and then he hops off to join the fight.
You look out at all the bodies everywhere...
"What have I done??? What have I done???"
Then you see an egg flying your way and you duck as it crashes through your window...
Before you can do anything, it beeps... then again, and again... faster and faster until...
With a bang you sit upright in bed, knocking the anchovie pizia onto the floor, and notice the TV playing a war movie...
Relaxed you check the time, 7:30, time to get up...
You check your phone... Saturday??? It's only Saturday??? Must have forgotten to clear the alarm clock...
(You go through your day, then go to bed...)
You are awaken at 2:30 am my someone knocking on the door...
You open it to see a small pink bunny holding an Easter basket...
"Sorry to bug you, but I need your help..."
[end]

Posts.EditableText: Hey DL, I like your idea of the player hiding the eggs.  That gives me an idea -- a game where author A creates a world with many hiding places.  Player B then wanders that world hiding eggs and saves the game.  Then player C reloads the game and has to find the eggs.
Posts.HTML: Hey DL, I like your idea of the player hiding the eggs. That gives me an idea -- a game where author A creates a world with many hiding places. Player B then wanders that world hiding eggs and saves the game. Then player C reloads the game and has to find the eggs.

Dcoder...
That would be real easy with BASIC where file reads and file writes are simple...
Actually... that could be the answer. 
A makes the world and uses code that would save the "egg hiding" locations...
B would play the game with the "hide" option, then select the hide locations which would be saved in the file.
C would play the game with the "hunt" option, the program would load the egg file, and "hide" the eggs...
If there is no egg file, the "hunt" option would not be allowed. 
Could be fun... 1 main world program, then we trade egg files to search for each other's hidden eggs...

Posts.EditableText:
@DL -
Exactly!  You could have 3 (or more) players, A, B, and C.  Each player creates a virtual world with hiding places.  Each player then passes their world to the next player in a clockwise fashion (A to B, B to C, C to A).  Then each player hides their eggs (B hides his eggs in A's world, C in B's world, etc.).  They pass worlds again and hunt for eggs in that world (B hunts in C's world, C in A's, etc.).  Scoring would be based on how many eggs you find in one world, and how many of your hidden eggs were not found in the other world.
Posts.HTML:
@DL -
Exactly! You could have 3 (or more) players, A, B, and C. Each player creates a virtual world with hiding places. Each player then passes their world to the next player in a clockwise fashion (A to B, B to C, C to A). Then each player hides their eggs (B hides his eggs in A's world, C in B's world, etc.). They pass worlds again and hunt for eggs in that world (B hunts in C's world, C in A's, etc.). Scoring would be based on how many eggs you find in one world, and how many of your hidden eggs were not found in the other world.

Posts.EditableText:
DL and DC,

A makes a Quest game with hiding spots and a container full of eggs, then emails the published game to B.

B plays the game, hiding all of the eggs, then saves the game.  B emails that save file to C.

C finds the eggs.

---
**NOTES:**

- B and C would need the Windows version of Quest.

- I don't *think* C would need the actual .quest file.  I think you can play from a save game without the original file.
Posts.HTML:
DL and DC,

A makes a Quest game with hiding spots and a container full of eggs, then emails the published game to B.

B plays the game, hiding all of the eggs, then saves the game. B emails that save file to C.

C finds the eggs.

NOTES:

  • B and C would need the Windows version of Quest.

  • I don't think C would need the actual .quest file. I think you can play from a save game without the original file.

Posts.EditableText:
In case anyone's amused, I've finally found time to take a look at this game.
Half an hour in, I have the following function. I would be highly amused to see if anyone can guess why an Easter game would require this function :p

<details>
<summary>Spoilers, maybe</summary>

```
 <function name="ContainsTea" parameters="room" type="boolean">
    return (ListCount(FilterByAttribute(GetAllChildObjects(from), "is_tea", true)) = 0)
  </function>
```

It's called 3 times from a function called `MoveTea (from, to)`, which is called from the `changedparent` script of all objects with the `is_tea` flag (currently a box of tea, a jar of tea, a teabag, a teapot, and a cup of tea). MoveTea itself is 55 lines of ugly script.
</details>
Posts.HTML:
In case anyone's amused, I've finally found time to take a look at this game.
Half an hour in, I have the following function. I would be highly amused to see if anyone can guess why an Easter game would require this function :p

Spoilers, maybe 
 <function name="ContainsTea" parameters="room" type="boolean">
    return (ListCount(FilterByAttribute(GetAllChildObjects(from), "is_tea", true)) = 0)
  </function>

It's called 3 times from a function called MoveTea (from, to), which is called from the changedparent script of all objects with the is_tea flag (currently a box of tea, a jar of tea, a teabag, a teapot, and a cup of tea). MoveTea itself is 55 lines of ugly script.
